hero.originalTitle: Study Shows Vaporizing E-Waste Makes it Easy to Recover Precious Metals at 13-Times Lower Costs
hero.headline: Scientists Turn E-Waste Into Treasure With Lightning-Hot Tech
hero.excerpt: Scientists have discovered a way to extract precious metals from electronic waste by heating it to 3,000°C with electrical current. The method creates no hazardous waste and could make recovering metals from e-waste 13 times cheaper than mining them from the ground.
hero.author: Al Gorithm

fullContent.lead: Scientists have discovered a way to extract precious metals from electronic waste by heating it to 3,000°C with electrical current. The method creates no hazardous waste and could make recovering metals from e-waste 13 times cheaper than mining them from the ground.

featured.originalTitle: Acupuncture for Rescued Elephants Provides Relief from Chronic Pain and Nerve Damage in India Care Center
featured.headline: Ancient Needlework Brings Modern Relief to Rescued Elephants
featured.excerpt: India's largest wildlife rescue organization is using acupuncture to help elephants recover from chronic pain and nerve damage after years of captivity or hard labor. The veterinary team trained in alternative medicine and found the techniques boosted recovery rates when used alongside conventional treatment.
featured.author: Finn Waters

fullContent.lead: India's largest wildlife rescue organization is using acupuncture to help elephants recover from chronic pain and nerve damage after years of captivity or hard labor. The veterinary team trained in alternative medicine and found the techniques boosted recovery rates when used alongside conventional treatment.

featured.originalTitle: A natural aging molecule may help restore memory in Alzheimer's
featured.headline: Body's Own Anti-Aging Molecule Could Be Key to Fighting Alzheimer's
featured.excerpt: Researchers have discovered that a natural aging-related molecule can repair key memory processes affected by Alzheimer's disease. The compound improves communication between brain cells and restores early memory abilities that typically fade first, potentially offering a safer way to protect the brain since it already exists in the body.
featured.author: Grace Recovery

fullContent.lead: Researchers have discovered that a natural aging-related molecule can repair key memory processes affected by Alzheimer's disease. The compound improves communication between brain cells and restores early memory abilities that typically fade first, potentially offering a safer way to protect the brain since it already exists in the body.

featured.headline: Living Drug Made From Patient's Own Cells Defeats 'Untreatable' Cancer
featured.excerpt: Gene therapy that turns white blood cells into a disease-fighting 'living drug' has successfully reversed previously untreatable blood cancers. The breakthrough treatment transforms patients' own immune cells into powerful cancer-fighting weapons.
featured.author: Vi Tality

fullContent.lead: Gene therapy that turns white blood cells into a disease-fighting 'living drug' has successfully reversed previously untreatable blood cancers. The breakthrough treatment transforms patients' own immune cells into powerful cancer-fighting weapons.

featured.originalTitle: At 67,800-years-old, These Handprints Just Discovered in Indonesia Are Oldest Example of Rock Art
featured.headline: Ancient Handprints Rewrite Human History by 67,800 Years
featured.excerpt: Stylized handprints discovered in an Indonesian limestone cave have broken records as the world's oldest-known rock art at 67,800 years old. The discovery provides direct evidence that humans were intentionally crossing seas for nearly 70,000 years as they traveled from Asia across waters.
featured.author: Crystal Clear

fullContent.lead: Stylized handprints discovered in an Indonesian limestone cave have broken records as the world's oldest-known rock art at 67,800 years old. The discovery provides direct evidence that humans were intentionally crossing seas for nearly 70,000 years as they traveled from Asia across waters.

featured.originalTitle: Nebraska Woman Learns to Row, Then Becomes First Female to Cross the Atlantic Alone in 3,000 Mile Race
featured.headline: From Landlocked Nebraska to Atlantic Record: Woman Makes Waves
featured.excerpt: Taryn Smith, inspired by ocean dreams while living in landlocked Nebraska, learned to row and became the first female to cross the Atlantic alone in a 3,000-mile race. The 25-year-old from Omaha was motivated after reading about an all-female rowing team that set a world record in the Great Pacific Race in 2022.
featured.author: Sol Idarity

fullContent.lead: Taryn Smith, inspired by ocean dreams while living in landlocked Nebraska, learned to row and became the first female to cross the Atlantic alone in a 3,000-mile race. The 25-year-old from Omaha was motivated after reading about an all-female rowing team that set a world record in the Great Pacific Race in 2022.

featured.originalTitle: Helping with Grandkids May Protect Against Cognitive Decline, Shows New Research
featured.headline: Grandparenting: The Brain Boost That Keeps on Giving
featured.excerpt: New research shows that being an involved grandparent may protect against cognitive decline and dementia in older adults. The study found that caring for grandchildren serves as a buffer against brain aging, supporting both families and the caregivers' mental health.
featured.author: Vi Tality

fullContent.lead: New research shows that being an involved grandparent may protect against cognitive decline and dementia in older adults. The study found that caring for grandchildren serves as a buffer against brain aging, supporting both families and the caregivers' mental health.

featured.originalTitle: Polar Bears are in Better Physical Shape than 25 Years Ago, Despite Sea Ice Losses
featured.headline: Plot Twist: Polar Bears Are Thriving Despite Climate Challenges
featured.excerpt: Polar bears around Norway's Svalbard island are in better physical health than they were 25 years ago, despite decreasing sea ice. The research revealed that the iconic white mammals have improved well-being in the face of climate change, likely due to better hunting opportunities.
featured.author: Finn Waters

fullContent.lead: Polar bears around Norway's Svalbard island are in better physical health than they were 25 years ago, despite decreasing sea ice. The research revealed that the iconic white mammals have improved well-being in the face of climate change, likely due to better hunting opportunities.

featured.originalTitle: Citizen Scientist Spots Earth-like Planet: Now Astrophysicists Will Focus Most Powerful Telescopes on it
featured.headline: Amateur Star-Gazer Discovers Earth's Cosmic Twin
featured.excerpt: Alexander Venner, a citizen scientist studying at the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, hand-picked his way through data to discover an Earth-like exoplanet. Astronomers are now excited to train the next generation of telescopes on this promising world that could harbor life.
featured.author: Ella Ment

fullContent.lead: Alexander Venner, a citizen scientist studying at the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, hand-picked his way through data to discover an Earth-like exoplanet. Astronomers are now excited to train the next generation of telescopes on this promising world that could harbor life.

featured.originalTitle: New catalyst turns carbon dioxide into clean fuel source
featured.headline: This Cheap Metal Just Made Carbon Dioxide Useful (And That's Pretty Cool)
featured.excerpt: Researchers discovered that manganese, an abundant and inexpensive metal, can efficiently convert carbon dioxide into formate, a potential hydrogen source for fuel cells. The improved manganese catalyst even outperformed many expensive precious-metal options, potentially turning greenhouse gas into clean energy ingredients.
featured.author: Forrest Green

fullContent.lead: Researchers discovered that manganese, an abundant and inexpensive metal, can efficiently convert carbon dioxide into formate, a potential hydrogen source for fuel cells. The improved manganese catalyst even outperformed many expensive precious-metal options, potentially turning greenhouse gas into clean energy ingredients.

featured.originalTitle: Scientists discover protein that could heal leaky gut and ease depression
featured.headline: Scientists Find the Missing Link Between Your Gut and Your Mood
featured.excerpt: New research shows that chronic stress damages the gut's protective lining by lowering levels of a protein called Reelin, which plays a key role in both gut repair and brain health. Remarkably, a single injection restored Reelin levels and produced antidepressant-like effects in preclinical models.
featured.author: Faith Healer

fullContent.lead: New research shows that chronic stress damages the gut's protective lining by lowering levels of a protein called Reelin, which plays a key role in both gut repair and brain health. Remarkably, a single injection restored Reelin levels and produced antidepressant-like effects in preclinical models.

featured.originalTitle: January 14th Marked the Longest Period Without a Nuclear Detonation Since the Atomic Age Began
featured.headline: We Just Hit a Nuclear Milestone (The Good Kind)
featured.excerpt: January 14th marked 8 years, 4 months, and 29 days since the last nuclear weapon was detonated on Earth. This represents the longest period without a nuclear detonation since the atomic age began in 1945.
featured.author: Hope Rising

fullContent.lead: January 14th marked 8 years, 4 months, and 29 days since the last nuclear weapon was detonated on Earth. This represents the longest period without a nuclear detonation since the atomic age began in 1945.

featured.originalTitle: New Ultrasonic Imaging System Can Detect Deadly Defects in All Types of Concrete
featured.headline: This Ultrasound Tech Could Save Lives (And It's Not for Babies)
featured.excerpt: Engineers developed a new ultrasonic imaging system that can detect dangerous defects inside concrete structures. Unlike previous methods with limited effectiveness, this technology works on all types of concrete regardless of the materials it contains like stone, clay, chalk, or slate.
featured.author: Adam Atom

fullContent.lead: Engineers developed a new ultrasonic imaging system that can detect dangerous defects inside concrete structures. Unlike previous methods with limited effectiveness, this technology works on all types of concrete regardless of the materials it contains like stone, clay, chalk, or slate.

featured.originalTitle: Farmers' Kids Cuddle Up with New Born Calf on the Couch After She Nearly Froze Outside
featured.headline: Kentucky Family Saves Newborn Calf with Ultimate Couch Cuddle Session
featured.excerpt: When single-digit temperatures threatened a newborn calf's survival over the weekend, Kentucky farmer Macey Sorrell brought the animal inside their home. The family's children cuddled up with the calf on their couch to help keep it warm and ensure its survival.
featured.author: Pat Ontheback

fullContent.lead: When single-digit temperatures threatened a newborn calf's survival over the weekend, Kentucky farmer Macey Sorrell brought the animal inside their home. The family's children cuddled up with the calf on their couch to help keep it warm and ensure its survival.

featured.originalTitle: Teens Build Igloo That Brings Together the Neighborhood After Difficult Ice Storm
featured.headline: Two Teens Built an Igloo That Melted Hearts (But Not From Heat)
featured.excerpt: While millions of Americans stayed indoors after ice storms hit the mid-Atlantic, teens Adeline Sutich and Maeve Ritchotte built an igloo in front of a house destroyed by fire months earlier. Their construction project brought the entire neighborhood together during a difficult time.
featured.author: Hope Rising

fullContent.lead: While millions of Americans stayed indoors after ice storms hit the mid-Atlantic, teens Adeline Sutich and Maeve Ritchotte built an igloo in front of a house destroyed by fire months earlier. Their construction project brought the entire neighborhood together during a difficult time.

climate.originalTitle: Scientists found the soil secret that doubles forest regrowth
climate.headline: Forests Found Their Growth Hack: It's All About the Nitrogen
climate.excerpt: New research shows tropical forests can recover twice as fast after deforestation when their soils contain enough nitrogen. Scientists followed forest regrowth across Central America for decades and found that nitrogen plays a decisive role in how quickly trees return, with faster regrowth also capturing more carbon from the atmosphere.
climate.author: Gusty Winds

fullContent.lead: New research shows tropical forests can recover twice as fast after deforestation when their soils contain enough nitrogen. Scientists followed forest regrowth across Central America for decades and found that nitrogen plays a decisive role in how quickly trees return, with faster regrowth also capturing more carbon from the atmosphere.

climate.originalTitle: Mexico moves to combat pollution following Guardian investigations
climate.headline: Mexico Takes Action Against Industrial Pollution
climate.excerpt: The Mexican government has announced a sweeping array of tactics to combat industrial pollution, including $4.8 million in fines against a plant processing US hazardous waste and the rollout of a new industrial air-monitoring system. The action follows investigations that revealed high levels of heavy-metal contamination in neighborhoods around factories in the Monterrey metropolitan area.
climate.author: Sunny Bright

fullContent.lead: The Mexican government has announced a sweeping array of tactics to combat industrial pollution, including $4.8 million in fines against a plant processing US hazardous waste and the rollout of a new industrial air-monitoring system. The action follows investigations that revealed high levels of heavy-metal contamination in neighborhoods around factories in the Monterrey metropolitan area.

climate.originalTitle: 750-year-old Indian poems reveal a landscape scientists got wrong
climate.headline: Ancient Poetry Schools Modern Scientists on Nature
climate.excerpt: Old Indian poems and folk songs are revealing that descriptions of thorny trees and open grasslands in texts written as far back as the 1200s closely match today's savannas in western India. This suggests these landscapes are ancient and natural—not ruined forests, which could reshape how conservation and tree-planting efforts are planned.
climate.author: Coral Reef

fullContent.lead: Old Indian poems and folk songs are revealing that descriptions of thorny trees and open grasslands in texts written as far back as the 1200s closely match today's savannas in western India. This suggests these landscapes are ancient and natural—not ruined forests, which could reshape how conservation and tree-planting efforts are planned.

health.originalTitle: Brain waves could help paralyzed patients move again
health.headline: Brain Waves Show Promise for Movement Recovery
health.excerpt: Researchers tested whether EEG brain scans could capture movement signals from people with spinal cord injuries and reroute them to spinal stimulators. The system can detect when a patient is trying to move, and scientists hope future improvements could turn intention into action for paralyzed patients.
health.author: Hope Springs

fullContent.lead: Researchers tested whether EEG brain scans could capture movement signals from people with spinal cord injuries and reroute them to spinal stimulators. science.originalTitle: UK launches plan to tackle 'forever chemicals' amid growing concerns
science.headline: UK Takes Forever Fight Against 'Forever Chemicals'
science.excerpt: The UK has launched its first ever national plan for tackling PFAS substances. The plan includes increasing testing for these persistent chemicals as part of a comprehensive strategy to address growing concerns about their environmental and health impacts.
science.author: Crystal Clear

fullContent.lead: The UK has launched its first ever national plan for tackling PFAS substances. The plan includes increasing testing for these persistent chemicals as part of a comprehensive strategy to address growing concerns about their environmental and health impacts.

science.originalTitle: Ancient tools in China are forcing scientists to rethink early humans
science.headline: Ancient Chinese Tools Show Early Humans Were Craftier Than We Thought
science.excerpt: Archaeologists in central China have uncovered evidence that early humans were far more inventive than long assumed. Excavations at the Xigou site reveal advanced stone tools, including the earliest known examples of tools fitted with handles in East Asia, dating back as far as 160,000 years.
science.author: Al Gorithm

fullContent.lead: Archaeologists in central China have uncovered evidence that early humans were far more inventive than long assumed. Excavations at the Xigou site reveal advanced stone tools, including the earliest known examples of tools fitted with handles in East Asia, dating back as far as 160,000 years.

science.originalTitle: A century-old Stonehenge mystery may finally be solved
science.headline: Stonehenge Mystery Gets Closer to Rock-Solid Solution
science.excerpt: Scientists have found compelling new evidence that humans, not glaciers, brought Stonehenge's bluestones to the site. Using advanced mineral analysis, researchers searched nearby river sediments for signs glaciers once passed through the area—and found none, strongly suggesting the stones were intentionally moved by people.
science.author: Adam Atom

fullContent.lead: Scientists have found compelling new evidence that humans, not glaciers, brought Stonehenge's bluestones to the site. Using advanced mineral analysis, researchers searched nearby river sediments for signs glaciers once passed through the area—and found none, strongly suggesting the stones were intentionally moved by people.

science.originalTitle: NASA's Perseverance rover completes the first AI-planned drive on Mars
science.headline: Mars Rover Takes First AI-Guided Road Trip
science.excerpt: NASA's Perseverance rover has made history by driving across Mars using routes planned by artificial intelligence instead of human operators. A vision-capable AI analyzed terrain data, identified hazards like rocks and sand ripples, and charted a safe path across the Martian surface, with Perseverance successfully following the AI-generated routes for hundreds of feet.
science.author: Adam Atom

fullContent.lead: NASA's Perseverance rover has made history by driving across Mars using routes planned by artificial intelligence instead of human operators. wildlife.originalTitle: 3,500-year-old rhino bone fragments found in Western Ghats rewrite India's wildlife map
wildlife.headline: Ancient Rhino Bones Rewrite India's Wild History
wildlife.excerpt: Archaeological findings of rhino bones near Coimbatore reveal the species once roamed southern India, significantly expanding its known ancient range. This discovery contrasts with current conservation data showing the one-horned rhinoceros is now confined to much smaller areas.
wildlife.author: Robin Nest

fullContent.lead: Archaeological findings of rhino bones near Coimbatore reveal the species once roamed southern India, significantly expanding its known ancient range. This discovery contrasts with current conservation data showing the one-horned rhinoceros is now confined to much smaller areas.

people.originalTitle: The Affordable Daycare That Keeps Parents Close
people.headline: This Daycare Solution Lets Parents Work AND Stay Close to Their Kids
people.excerpt: A coworking space in Michigan offers on-site childcare that keeps parents physically close to their children during the workday. The model provides an affordable alternative to traditional daycare while allowing parents to be nearby when their kids need them.
people.author: Pat Ontheback

people.originalTitle: The Whimsical Floating Schools of Kashmir
people.headline: These Floating Schools Turn Daily Commutes Into Magic
people.excerpt: Each weekday morning on Kashmir's Dal Lake, children in school uniforms travel by wooden boats from their houseboats and island homes to school. Some row themselves while others are ferried by family, creating a unique educational journey across the water.
people.author: Hope Rising

The discovery provides direct evidence that humans were intentionally crossing seas for nearly 70,000 years as they traveled from Asia across waters.

allArticles.originalTitle: Nebraska Woman Learns to Row, Then Becomes First Female to Cross the Atlantic Alone in 3,000 Mile Race
allArticles.headline: From Landlocked Nebraska to Atlantic Record: Woman Makes Waves
allArticles.excerpt: Taryn Smith, inspired by ocean dreams while living in landlocked Nebraska, learned to row and became the first female to cross the Atlantic alone in a 3,000-mile race. The 25-year-old from Omaha was motivated after reading about an all-female rowing team that set a world record in the Great Pacific Race in 2022.
allArticles.author: Sol Idarity

fullContent.lead: Taryn Smith, inspired by ocean dreams while living in landlocked Nebraska, learned to row and became the first female to cross the Atlantic alone in a 3,000-mile race. The 25-year-old from Omaha was motivated after reading about an all-female rowing team that set a world record in the Great Pacific Race in 2022.

allArticles.originalTitle: Helping with Grandkids May Protect Against Cognitive Decline, Shows New Research
allArticles.headline: Grandparenting: The Brain Boost That Keeps on Giving
allArticles.excerpt: New research shows that being an involved grandparent may protect against cognitive decline and dementia in older adults. The study found that caring for grandchildren serves as a buffer against brain aging, supporting both families and the caregivers' mental health.
allArticles.author: Vi Tality

allArticles.originalTitle: Polar Bears are in Better Physical Shape than 25 Years Ago, Despite Sea Ice Losses
allArticles.headline: Plot Twist: Polar Bears Are Thriving Despite Climate Challenges
allArticles.excerpt: Polar bears around Norway's Svalbard island are in better physical health than they were 25 years ago, despite decreasing sea ice. The research revealed that the iconic white mammals have improved well-being in the face of climate change, likely due to better hunting opportunities.
allArticles.author: Finn Waters

fullContent.lead: Polar bears around Norway's Svalbard island are in better physical health than they were 25 years ago, despite decreasing sea ice. The research revealed that the iconic white mammals have improved well-being in the face of climate change, likely due to better hunting opportunities.

allArticles.originalTitle: Citizen Scientist Spots Earth-like Planet: Now Astrophysicists Will Focus Most Powerful Telescopes on it
allArticles.headline: Amateur Star-Gazer Discovers Earth's Cosmic Twin
allArticles.excerpt: Alexander Venner, a citizen scientist studying at the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, hand-picked his way through data to discover an Earth-like exoplanet. Astronomers are now excited to train the next generation of telescopes on this promising world that could harbor life.
allArticles.author: Ella Ment

fullContent.lead: Alexander Venner, a citizen scientist studying at the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, hand-picked his way through data to discover an Earth-like exoplanet. Astronomers are now excited to train the next generation of telescopes on this promising world that could harbor life.

allArticles.originalTitle: New catalyst turns carbon dioxide into clean fuel source
allArticles.headline: This Cheap Metal Just Made Carbon Dioxide Useful (And That's Pretty Cool)
allArticles.excerpt: Researchers discovered that manganese, an abundant and inexpensive metal, can efficiently convert carbon dioxide into formate, a potential hydrogen source for fuel cells. The improved manganese catalyst even outperformed many expensive precious-metal options, potentially turning greenhouse gas into clean energy ingredients.
allArticles.author: Forrest Green

fullContent.lead: Researchers discovered that manganese, an abundant and inexpensive metal, can efficiently convert carbon dioxide into formate, a potential hydrogen source for fuel cells. The improved manganese catalyst even outperformed many expensive precious-metal options, potentially turning greenhouse gas into clean energy ingredients.

allArticles.originalTitle: Scientists discover protein that could heal leaky gut and ease depression
allArticles.headline: Scientists Find the Missing Link Between Your Gut and Your Mood
allArticles.excerpt: New research shows that chronic stress damages the gut's protective lining by lowering levels of a protein called Reelin, which plays a key role in both gut repair and brain health. Remarkably, a single injection restored Reelin levels and produced antidepressant-like effects in preclinical models.
allArticles.author: Faith Healer

Remarkably, a single injection restored Reelin levels and produced antidepressant-like effects in preclinical models.

allArticles.originalTitle: January 14th Marked the Longest Period Without a Nuclear Detonation Since the Atomic Age Began
allArticles.headline: We Just Hit a Nuclear Milestone (The Good Kind)
allArticles.excerpt: January 14th marked 8 years, 4 months, and 29 days since the last nuclear weapon was detonated on Earth. This represents the longest period without a nuclear detonation since the atomic age began in 1945.
allArticles.author: Hope Rising

fullContent.lead: January 14th marked 8 years, 4 months, and 29 days since the last nuclear weapon was detonated on Earth. This represents the longest period without a nuclear detonation since the atomic age began in 1945.

allArticles.originalTitle: New Ultrasonic Imaging System Can Detect Deadly Defects in All Types of Concrete
allArticles.headline: This Ultrasound Tech Could Save Lives (And It's Not for Babies)
allArticles.excerpt: Engineers developed a new ultrasonic imaging system that can detect dangerous defects inside concrete structures. Unlike previous methods with limited effectiveness, this technology works on all types of concrete regardless of the materials it contains like stone, clay, chalk, or slate.
allArticles.author: Adam Atom

fullContent.lead: Engineers developed a new ultrasonic imaging system that can detect dangerous defects inside concrete structures. Unlike previous methods with limited effectiveness, this technology works on all types of concrete regardless of the materials it contains like stone, clay, chalk, or slate.

allArticles.originalTitle: Farmers' Kids Cuddle Up with New Born Calf on the Couch After She Nearly Froze Outside
allArticles.headline: Kentucky Family Saves Newborn Calf with Ultimate Couch Cuddle Session
allArticles.excerpt: When single-digit temperatures threatened a newborn calf's survival over the weekend, Kentucky farmer Macey Sorrell brought the animal inside their home. The family's children cuddled up with the calf on their couch to help keep it warm and ensure its survival.
allArticles.author: Pat Ontheback

allArticles.originalTitle: Teens Build Igloo That Brings Together the Neighborhood After Difficult Ice Storm
allArticles.headline: Two Teens Built an Igloo That Melted Hearts (But Not From Heat)
allArticles.excerpt: While millions of Americans stayed indoors after ice storms hit the mid-Atlantic, teens Adeline Sutich and Maeve Ritchotte built an igloo in front of a house destroyed by fire months earlier. Their construction project brought the entire neighborhood together during a difficult time.
allArticles.author: Hope Rising

fullContent.lead: While millions of Americans stayed indoors after ice storms hit the mid-Atlantic, teens Adeline Sutich and Maeve Ritchotte built an igloo in front of a house destroyed by fire months earlier. Their construction project brought the entire neighborhood together during a difficult time.

allArticles.originalTitle: The Affordable Daycare That Keeps Parents Close
allArticles.headline: This Daycare Solution Lets Parents Work AND Stay Close to Their Kids
allArticles.excerpt: A coworking space in Michigan offers on-site childcare that keeps parents physically close to their children during the workday. The model provides an affordable alternative to traditional daycare while allowing parents to be nearby when their kids need them.
allArticles.author: Pat Ontheback

fullContent.lead: A coworking space in Michigan offers on-site childcare that keeps parents physically close to their children during the workday. The model provides an affordable alternative to traditional daycare while allowing parents to be nearby when their kids need them.

allArticles.originalTitle: The Whimsical Floating Schools of Kashmir
allArticles.headline: These Floating Schools Turn Daily Commutes Into Magic
allArticles.excerpt: Each weekday morning on Kashmir's Dal Lake, children in school uniforms travel by wooden boats from their houseboats and island homes to school. Some row themselves while others are ferried by family, creating a unique educational journey across the water.
allArticles.author: Hope Rising

fullContent.lead: Each weekday morning on Kashmir's Dal Lake, children in school uniforms travel by wooden boats from their houseboats and island homes to school. Some row themselves while others are ferried by family, creating a unique educational journey across the water.

allArticles.originalTitle: Scientists found the soil secret that doubles forest regrowth
allArticles.headline: Forests Found Their Growth Hack: It's All About the Nitrogen
allArticles.excerpt: New research shows tropical forests can recover twice as fast after deforestation when their soils contain enough nitrogen. Scientists followed forest regrowth across Central America for decades and found that nitrogen plays a decisive role in how quickly trees return, with faster regrowth also capturing more carbon from the atmosphere.
allArticles.author: Gusty Winds

Scientists followed forest regrowth across Central America for decades and found that nitrogen plays a decisive role in how quickly trees return, with faster regrowth also capturing more carbon from the atmosphere.

allArticles.originalTitle: UK launches plan to tackle 'forever chemicals' amid growing concerns
allArticles.headline: UK Takes Forever Fight Against 'Forever Chemicals'
allArticles.excerpt: The UK has launched its first ever national plan for tackling PFAS substances. The plan includes increasing testing for these persistent chemicals as part of a comprehensive strategy to address growing concerns about their environmental and health impacts.
allArticles.author: Crystal Clear

fullContent.lead: The UK has launched its first ever national plan for tackling PFAS substances. The plan includes increasing testing for these persistent chemicals as part of a comprehensive strategy to address growing concerns about their environmental and health impacts.

allArticles.originalTitle: 3,500-year-old rhino bone fragments found in Western Ghats rewrite India's wildlife map
allArticles.headline: Ancient Rhino Bones Rewrite India's Wild History
allArticles.excerpt: Archaeological findings of rhino bones near Coimbatore reveal the species once roamed southern India, significantly expanding its known ancient range. This discovery contrasts with current conservation data showing the one-horned rhinoceros is now confined to much smaller areas.
allArticles.author: Robin Nest

fullContent.lead: Archaeological findings of rhino bones near Coimbatore reveal the species once roamed southern India, significantly expanding its known ancient range. This discovery contrasts with current conservation data showing the one-horned rhinoceros is now confined to much smaller areas.

allArticles.originalTitle: Mexico moves to combat pollution following Guardian investigations
allArticles.headline: Mexico Takes Action Against Industrial Pollution
allArticles.excerpt: The Mexican government has announced a sweeping array of tactics to combat industrial pollution, including $4.8 million in fines against a plant processing US hazardous waste and the rollout of a new industrial air-monitoring system. The action follows investigations that revealed high levels of heavy-metal contamination in neighborhoods around factories in the Monterrey metropolitan area.
allArticles.author: Sunny Bright

fullContent.lead: The Mexican government has announced a sweeping array of tactics to combat industrial pollution, including $4.8 million in fines against a plant processing US hazardous waste and the rollout of a new industrial air-monitoring system. The action follows investigations that revealed high levels of heavy-metal contamination in neighborhoods around factories in the Monterrey metropolitan area.

allArticles.originalTitle: 750-year-old Indian poems reveal a landscape scientists got wrong
allArticles.headline: Ancient Poetry Schools Modern Scientists on Nature
allArticles.excerpt: Old Indian poems and folk songs are revealing that descriptions of thorny trees and open grasslands in texts written as far back as the 1200s closely match today's savannas in western India. This suggests these landscapes are ancient and natural—not ruined forests, which could reshape how conservation and tree-planting efforts are planned.
allArticles.author: Coral Reef

fullContent.lead: Old Indian poems and folk songs are revealing that descriptions of thorny trees and open grasslands in texts written as far back as the 1200s closely match today's savannas in western India. This suggests these landscapes are ancient and natural—not ruined forests, which could reshape how conservation and tree-planting efforts are planned.

allArticles.originalTitle: Ancient tools in China are forcing scientists to rethink early humans
allArticles.headline: Ancient Chinese Tools Show Early Humans Were Craftier Than We Thought
allArticles.excerpt: Archaeologists in central China have uncovered evidence that early humans were far more inventive than long assumed. Excavations at the Xigou site reveal advanced stone tools, including the earliest known examples of tools fitted with handles in East Asia, dating back as far as 160,000 years.
allArticles.author: Al Gorithm

fullContent.lead: Archaeologists in central China have uncovered evidence that early humans were far more inventive than long assumed. Excavations at the Xigou site reveal advanced stone tools, including the earliest known examples of tools fitted with handles in East Asia, dating back as far as 160,000 years.

allArticles.originalTitle: A century-old Stonehenge mystery may finally be solved
allArticles.headline: Stonehenge Mystery Gets Closer to Rock-Solid Solution
allArticles.excerpt: Scientists have found compelling new evidence that humans, not glaciers, brought Stonehenge's bluestones to the site. Using advanced mineral analysis, researchers searched nearby river sediments for signs glaciers once passed through the area—and found none, strongly suggesting the stones were intentionally moved by people.
allArticles.author: Adam Atom

fullContent.lead: Scientists have found compelling new evidence that humans, not glaciers, brought Stonehenge's bluestones to the site. Using advanced mineral analysis, researchers searched nearby river sediments for signs glaciers once passed through the area—and found none, strongly suggesting the stones were intentionally moved by people.

allArticles.originalTitle: Brain waves could help paralyzed patients move again
allArticles.headline: Brain Waves Show Promise for Movement Recovery
allArticles.excerpt: Researchers tested whether EEG brain scans could capture movement signals from people with spinal cord injuries and reroute them to spinal stimulators. The system can detect when a patient is trying to move, and scientists hope future improvements could turn intention into action for paralyzed patients.
allArticles.author: Hope Springs

fullContent.lead: Researchers tested whether EEG brain scans could capture movement signals from people with spinal cord injuries and reroute them to spinal stimulators. The system can detect when a patient is trying to move, and scientists hope future improvements could turn intention into action for paralyzed patients.

allArticles.originalTitle: NASA's Perseverance rover completes the first AI-planned drive on Mars
allArticles.headline: Mars Rover Takes First AI-Guided Road Trip
allArticles.excerpt: NASA's Perseverance rover has made history by driving across Mars using routes planned by artificial intelligence instead of human operators. A vision-capable AI analyzed terrain data, identified hazards like rocks and sand ripples, and charted a safe path across the Martian surface, with Perseverance successfully following the AI-generated routes for hundreds of feet.
allArticles.author: Adam Atom
